back.definition: to cause someone to have a particular feeling
examples: The movie's suspenseful scenes really *arouse* my curiosity.
The passionate speech *aroused* strong emotions in the audience.

back.definition: the causing of strong feelings or excitement in someone
examples: His speech caused an *arousal* of patriotic fervor among the crowd.
The music created a sense of *arousal* in the listeners.

back.definition: quite, but not extremely
examples: The hike was *pretty* challenging, but we made it to the top.
She's *pretty* confident that she'll pass the exam.

back.definition: attractive in a delicate way without being truly beautiful
examples: The garden was filled with *pretty* flowers.
She wore a *pretty* dress to the party.

back.definition: to make something look more attractive
examples: She decided to *prettify* the room with some colorful decorations.
Adding a few accessories can *prettify* even the simplest outfit.

back.definition: impressive and large or important
examples: The palace was a *grand* structure with towering spires.
She made a *grand* entrance at the party.

back.definition: the amount of space that is contained within an object or solid shape
examples: The *volume* of the box is calculated by multiplying its length, width, and height.
You can adjust the *volume* of the music using the control knob.

back.definition: the level of sound produced by a television, radio, etc.
examples: Please turn up the *volume* so we can hear the movie better.
The *volume* of the music was so loud that it could be heard from the next room.

back.definition: a book, especially one that is part of a series
examples: She has a large collection of *volumes* from the fantasy series.
The library contains several *volumes* of historical documents.

back.definition: to make a picture of something or someone with a pencil or pen
examples: He likes to *draw* landscapes in his sketchbook.
She *drew* a portrait of her friend for their birthday.

back.definition: to pull or direct something in a particular direction
examples: He *drew* the curtains closed to block out the sunlight.
The magnet *draws* metal objects toward it.

back.definition: a large bus with comfortable seats used for long journeys
examples: We traveled to the city by *coach*.
The *coach* ride was smooth and comfortable.

back.definition: someone whose job is to teach people to improve at a sport, skill, or school subject
examples: The basketball *coach* trained the team every day.
She hired a private *coach* to help her preparefor the exam.

back.definition: to give someone something that they need
examples: The company *provided* all employees with laptops.
Parents must *provide* food and shelter for their children.

back.definition: a company or person that gives you something you need
examples: The internet *provider* offers high-speed connections to its customers.
She works as a healthcare *provider* in a local clinic.

back.definition: the act of providing something
examples: The *provision* of food and water is essential during a disaster.
The government made *provisions* for housing displaced families.

back.definition: to deal successfully with a difficult situation
examples: She struggled to *cope with* the loss of her loved one.
She's finding it hard to *cope with* the pressure of her new job.

back.definition: the particular state that something or someone is in
examples: The car was in excellent *condition* after being serviced.
He's in no *condition* to drive after drinking.

back.definition: an arrangement that must exist before something else can happen
examples: Meeting this *condition* is necessary for the agreement.
The *condition* of the equipment must be checked regularly.

back.definition: to (cause to) arrive on the ground or other surface after moving down through the air
examples: The plane will *land* at the airport in an hour.
The bird gracefully *lands* on the branch.

back.definition: the surface of the earth that is not covered by water
examples: They bought a house with a large plot of *land*.
The farmer works the *land* to grow crops.

back.definition: the area that is included in or dealt with by something; space or opportunity for action, thought, etc.
examples: The project was beyond the *scope* of our resources.
She widened the *scope* of her investigation.

back.definition: a group of similar things or people, especially one that you can hold in your hand or carry.
examples: He bought a *pack* of gum at the store.
A *pack* of wolves roamed the forest.

back.definition: an object or group of objects wrapped in paper or plastic, or packed in a box.
examples: The *package* was delivered to my door.
She received a *package* in the mail.

back.definition: an activity involving skill in making things by hand.
examples: She enjoys practicing her *craft* on weekends.
The artisan displayed his *craft* at the fair.

back.definition: a person who is skilled in a particular craft.
examples: The *craftsman* carved a beautiful sculpture.
He is a skilled *craftsman* in woodworking.

back.definition: clever at achieving one's aims by indirect or deceitful methods.
examples: The *crafty* fox evaded capture.
She devised a *crafty* plan to get what she wanted.

back.definition: the value of something measured by its qualities or by the esteem in which it is held.
examples: The book's *worth* was evident by its high price.
He proved his *worth* to the team.

back.definition: having qualities that deserve your respect, attention, or admiration.
examples: She is a *worthy* recipient of the award.
His actions were deemed *worthy* of praise.

back.definition: relating to a city or town.
examples: The *urban* landscape was filled with skyscrapers.
He enjoys the *urban* lifestyle.

back.definition: a small body of still water formed naturally or by artificial means.
examples: They went fishing in the *pond*.
A family of ducks lived in the *pond*.

back.definition: easy to recognize because of being seen, met, heard, etc before
examples: She felt *familiar* with the surroundings.
The sound of the old clock was *familiar* to him.

back.definition: close acquaintance with or knowledge of something
examples: His *familiarity* with the subject made the lecture interesting.
She has a deep *familiarity* with local customs.

back.definition: not known or recognized
examples: The terrain was completely *unfamiliar* to them.
He felt *unfamiliar* with the new software.

back.definition: to give (someone) knowledge or understanding of something
examples: The teacher tried to *familiarize* the students with the new concept.
He took a moment to *familiarize* himself with the controls.

back.definition: to hit something gently, and often repeatedly, especially making short sharp noises
examples: He *tapped* the table with his pen.
She gently *tapped* on the door.

back.definition: a device by which a flow of liquid or gas from a pipe or container can be controlled
examples: Turn off the *tap* when not in use.
The kitchen *tap* was leaking.

back.definition: an upright pillar, typically cylindrical, supporting an arch or other structure or standing alone as a monument
examples: The ancient *columns* were still standing.
He admired the Greek *columns* in the old temple.

back.definition: the fact of having committed a specified or implied offense or crime
examples: He felt a deep sense of *guilt* after the accident.
The evidence clearly showed her *guilt*.

back.definition: having committed an offense, crime, or wrong, especially against moral or penal law
examples: The jury found him *guilty* of all charges.
She felt *guilty* about lying to her friend.

back.definition: either of the two long parts of the upper body that are attached to the shoulders and have the hands at the end.
examples: He broke his *arm* while playing football.
She raised her *arm* to ask a question.

back.definition: the part of the arm between the elbow and the wrist.
examples: He has a tattoo on his *forearm*.
She felt pain in her *forearm* after lifting the weights.

back.definition: a room used for a special or official purpose, or a group of people who form (part of) a parliament.
examples: The meeting was held in the council *chamber*.
The heart has four *chambers*.

back.definition: to need to pay or give something to someone because they have lent money to you, or in exchange for something they have done for you.
examples: I *owe* you ten dollars.
She still *owes* money on her car loan.

back.definition: to contain something as a part of something else, or to make something part of something else.
examples: The tour *includes* a visit to the museum.
Please *include* your contact information in the email.

back.definition: the fact of including someone or something, especially as part of a group, list, etc.
examples: The *inclusion* of more women in the workforce is vital.
His *inclusion* in the team was a great decision.

back.definition: containing all; not keeping any out.
examples: We aim to create an *inclusive* environment.
The price is *inclusive* of taxes.

back.definition: in a way that includes everyone and everything.
examples: The policy applies *inclusively* to all employees.
We need to think *inclusively* to solve this problem.

back.definition: to choose someone officially for a job or responsibility.
examples: They decided to *appoint* a new manager.
She was *appointed* to the board of directors.

back.definition: a formal arrangement to meet or visit someone at a particular time and place.
examples: I have a dentist *appointment* tomorrow.
She scheduled an *appointment* with the doctor.

back.definition: the act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself.
examples: His *appointment* as CEO was unexpected.
The *appointment* of the new judge was confirmed.

back.definition: to take part in special enjoyable activities in order to show that a particular occasion is important
examples: We always *celebrate* birthdays with a cake.
They *celebrated* their anniversary by going out for dinner.

back.definition: a special social event, such as a party, when you celebrate something
examples: The town held a big *celebration* for the holiday.
We had a *celebration* after the graduation ceremony.

back.definition: celebrating an important event or a special occasion
examples: There was a *celebratory* dinner for the award winners.
She gave a *celebratory* speech at the event.

back.definition: to use something for the wrong purpose in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
examples: He was accused of *abusing* his power.
The law protects against *abuse* of animals.

back.definition: using rude and offensive words
examples: He was fired for making *abusive* comments.
The manager's *abusive* language shocked everyone.

back.definition: to break up and move soil using a tool, a machine, or your hands
examples: He loves to *dig* in the garden.
We need to *dig* a hole for the new tree.

back.definition: the way that someone behaves
examples: His *behavior* in class is always exemplary.
We need to address her disruptive *behavior*.

back.definition: a set of wires, covered by plastic, that carries electricity, phone signals, etc.
examples: The internet *cable* needs to be replaced.
She tripped over the *cable* in the hallway.

back.definition: able to learn, understand, and think about things quickly and easily
examples: She is an *intelligent* student who excels in all subjects.
The *intelligent* design of the system makes it easy to use.

back.definition: the ability to learn, understand, and think about things
examples: His *intelligence* is evident in the way he solves complex problems.
Artificial *intelligence* is revolutionizing many industries.

back.definition: to agree that something is true, especially unwillingly
examples: He had to *admit* his mistake.
She reluctantly *admitted* to breaking the vase.

back.definition: the act of agreeing that something is true, especially unwillingly
examples: Her *admission* of guilt surprised everyone.
The *admission* fee to the museum is $10.

back.definition: used when you are agreeing that something is true, especially unwillingly
examples: *Admittedly*, it was a difficult challenge.
*Admittedly*, I was wrong about the issue.

back.definition: the thick, yellowish-white liquid that forms on the top of milk
examples: Would you like some *cream* in your coffee?
She whipped the *cream* until it was thick.

back.definition: thick and smooth like cream; containing cream
examples: The soup has a *creamy* texture.
She prefers *creamy* sauces for her pasta.

back.definition: to take something for your own use, usually without permission
examples: He tried to *appropriate* the funds for personal use.
The company *appropriated* the new technology without permission.

back.definition: suitable or right for a particular situation or occasion
examples: Her outfit was *appropriate* for the occasion.
It is important to wear *appropriate* attire to a job interview.

back.definition: the act of taking something for your own use, usually without permission
examples: The *appropriation* of public funds is illegal.
He was accused of cultural *appropriation*.

back.definition: the part of a plant that grows down into the earth to get water and food and holds the plant firm in the ground
examples: The tree's *roots* are deep and strong.
She pulled the weed out by the *root*.

back.definition: to examine or look for the differences between persons or things
examples: It is difficult to *compare* apples with oranges.
She always *compares* prices before buying anything.

back.definition: similar in size, amount, or quality to something else
examples: The new model is *comparable* to the old one.
Their results are not directly *comparable* with each other.

back.definition: so good or great that nothing or no one else could achieve the same standard
examples: Her beauty is *incomparable* to anyone else's.
The view from the mountain top is simply *incomparable*.

back.definition: involving the comparison of two or more things
examples: We conducted a *comparative* study between the two groups.
She made a *comparative* analysis of the data.

back.definition: as compared to something else
examples: The exam was *comparatively* easy compared to last year's.
Living costs are *comparatively* high in this area.

back.definition: being, relating to, or belonging to a person or to people as opposed to animals
examples: Every *human* has the right to freedom.
The *human* body is capable of amazing things.

back.definition: extremely cruel; not having the qualities of kindness, pity, or sympathy that people usually have
examples: His treatment of the prisoners was *inhuman*.
The dictator's actions were *inhuman* by any standard.

back.definition: people in general; all people
examples: We must strive for the betterment of *humanity*.
Acts of kindness restore faith in *humanity*.

back.definition: to kill in a violent way
examples: The dragon was *slain* by the knight.
He *slew* his enemies with great ferocity.

back.definition: to continue to exist past the usual time, or to continue to do something in a determined way even when facing difficulties or opposition
examples: She *persisted* in her efforts despite the challenges.
If symptoms *persist*, consult your doctor.

back.definition: lasting for a long time or difficult to get rid of
examples: He has been *persistent* in asking for a promotion.
The rain has been *persistent* throughout the week.

back.definition: the fact that someone or something persists
examples: Her *persistence* in achieving her goals is admirable.
The *persistence* of the cold weather is unusual for this time of year.

back.definition: having a larger distance from one side to the other than is usual or expected
examples: The river is very *wide* at this point.
She has a *wide* range of interests.

back.definition: to become, or to make something become, wider
examples: They plan to *widen* the road to accommodate more traffic.
Her eyes *widened* with surprise.

back.definition: the distance across something from one side to the other
examples: The *width* of the table is too large for the room.
Please measure the *width* of the doorway before buying new furniture.

back.definition: one of four equal or almost equal parts of something; ¼
examples: He ate a *quarter* of the pizza.
The city is divided into four *quarters*.

back.definition: to disappear suddenly and/or in a way that you cannot explain
examples: The magician made the rabbit *vanish*.
She watched him *vanish* into the crowd.

back.definition: to mix a liquid or other substance by moving an object such as a spoon in a circular pattern
examples: Please *stir* the soup slowly.
He began to *stir* in his sleep.

back.definition: a hole or space that something or someone can pass through
examples: They crawled through a small *opening* in the fence.
Make sure the *opening* is large enough for the cable.

back.definition: a person who works in a library
examples: The *librarian* helped me find the book.
She asked the *librarian* for assistance.

back.definition: a connection between two people, things, or ideas
examples: There is a *link* between smoking and lung cancer.
They established a *link* between the two crimes.

back.definition: one ring of a chain
examples: Each *link* in the chain is strong.
He fixed the broken *link* in the chain.

back.definition: the act of linking things together or the state of being linked together
examples: The *linkage* between the two systems is crucial.
They studied the *linkage* of genetic traits.

back.definition: to remove what is covering something so that it can be seen
examples: They *exposed* the painting to direct sunlight.
The investigation *exposed* the fraud.

back.definition: a show in which industrial goods, works of art, etc. are shown to the public
examples: The art *exposition* will be held downtown.
He visited the industrial *exposition* last weekend.

back.definition: to tell a story, often by reading aloud from a text, or to describe events as they happen
examples: She *narrated* the story with great emotion.
The documentary was *narrated* by a famous actor.

back.definition: a story or a description of a series of events
examples: His *narrative* was both engaging and informative.
The book provides a fascinating *narrative* of her journey.

back.definition: the act of telling a story
examples: The *narration* of the documentary was done by a professional.
His *narration* kept the audience engaged.

back.definition: to make someone able to do something, or to make something possible
examples: This software *enables* users to create stunning graphics.
Her support *enabled* him to achieve his goals.

back.definition: a strong stick or metal bar with a pointed end
examples: He drove a *stake* into the ground to support the tent.
The vampire was defeated with a wooden *stake*.

back.definition: a share or a financial involvement in something such as a business
examples: She has a significant *stake* in the company.
They decided to *stake* everything on this new venture.

back.definition: socially acceptable or good
examples: He is a *decent* person who always helps others.
She wore a *decent* dress to the party.

back.definition: not suitable or not acceptable, especially because of being shocking or offensive
examples: His *indecent* behavior caused a scandal.
The movie was criticized for its *indecent* content.

back.definition: behavior that is good, moral, and acceptable in society
examples: He is a man of great *decency* and integrity.
Her actions reflected her *decency*.

back.definition: behavior that is morally or sexually offensive
examples: He was fined for public *indecency*.
The show was criticized for its *indecency*.

back.definition: a piece of clothing that is worn on the hand and wrist for warmth or protection, with separate parts for each finger.
examples: She put on her *gloves* before going outside.
He took off his *gloves* after shoveling snow.

back.definition: to make someone with an illness healthy again.
examples: The doctor managed to *cure* the patient.
They are working to *cure* the disease.

back.definition: able to be cured.
examples: The illness is *curable* if treated early.
Some diseases are not *curable*.

back.definition: not able to be cured.
examples: Unfortunately, the condition is *incurable*.
He was diagnosed with an *incurable* disease.

back.definition: able to cure or cause to get better.
examples: The *curative* properties of the herb were well-known.
This medicine has a *curative* effect on infections.

back.definition: to stay away from someone or something.
examples: She tries to *avoid* talking to him.
He *avoids* junk food to stay healthy.

back.definition: the act of avoiding something or someone.
examples: His *avoidance* of conflict is well-known.
She developed an *avoidance* of crowded places.

back.definition: to consider an idea or plan carefully before making a decision.
examples: I need to *think over* your offer.
He took some time to *think over* his options.

back.definition: to carefully consider the possible results of doing something.
examples: She always *thinks through* her plans.
You need to *think through* the consequences.

back.definition: to appear by coming out of something or out from behind something.
examples: A figure *emerged* from the shadows.
The truth finally *emerged* after years of silence.

back.definition: starting to exist or to become known.
examples: The *emergent* technology is still in its infancy.
He is an *emergent* talent in the industry.

back.definition: the fact of something becoming known or starting to exist.
examples: The *emergence* of new markets has boosted the economy.
We witnessed the *emergence* of a new era.

back.definition: someone who catches fish, especially as a job
examples: The *fisherman* went out to sea early in the morning.
She bought fresh fish from the local *fisherman*.

back.definition: an area of water where fish are caught so they can be sold
examples: The government regulates the *fishery* to prevent overfishing.
He invested in a *fishery* along the coast.

back.definition: awake, thinking, and knowing what is happening around you
examples: She was fully *conscious* during the operation.
He made a *conscious* effort to improve his behavior.

back.definition: in the state of not being awake and not aware of things around you, especially as the result of a head injury
examples: He was knocked *unconscious* during the fight.
She lay *unconscious* on the floor after the accident.

back.definition: the state of understanding and realizing something
examples: He regained *consciousness* after a few minutes.
Her *consciousness* of the situation grew as she listened.

back.definition: the part of your mind that contains feelings and thoughts that you do not know about, and that influences the way you behave
examples: His fear of dogs is rooted in his *subconscious* mind.
The dream revealed her *subconscious* worries.

back.definition: the state of not being aware of something that influences your thoughts or behavior
examples: Her *subconsciousness* influences her decisions without her knowing.
The therapist explored his *subconsciousness* to understand his behavior.

back.definition: to notice something that is partly hidden or not clear, or to discover something, especially using a special method
examples: The machine can *detect* even the smallest defects.
He was able to *detect* the scent of flowers in the air.

back.definition: in, at, or to any place
examples: You can sit *anywhere* you like.
He couldn’t find his keys *anywhere*.

back.definition: in a way that is not organized or tidy
examples: The tools were just left *anyhow* in the shed.
She threw her clothes *anyhow* into the suitcase.

back.definition: to be brave enough to do something difficult or dangerous
examples: He didn’t *dare* to jump off the cliff.
She *dared* him to eat the spicy pepper.

back.definition: a strong feeling of displeasure or hostility
examples: He felt a surge of *anger* at the injustice.
She couldn't hide her *anger* with him.

back.definition: a collection of things or materials that are not specified
examples: I need to pack all my *stuff* for the trip.
She loves buying new *stuff* for her house.

back.definition: having good luck; lucky
examples: He was *fortunate* to find a good job so quickly.
She considered herself *fortunate* to have such supportive friends.

back.definition: happening because of good luck
examples: *Fortunately*, the weather was perfect for the picnic.
We were *fortunately* able to get tickets to the concert.

back.definition: happening because of bad luck
examples: *Unfortunately*, we missed the last train home.
He *unfortunately* had to cancel his trip due to illness.

back.definition: having bad luck; unlucky
examples: It was an *unfortunate* accident that could have been prevented.
They were *unfortunate* to lose their home in the fire.

back.definition: an area of land that has not been developed or is in its natural state
examples: They went on a hike through the *wilderness*.
The cabin is located in the heart of the *wilderness*.

back.definition: to prevent someone or something from entering a place
examples: We need to *shut out* the noise from the street.
She felt *shut out* from the group.

back.definition: to prevent someone or something from leaving a place
examples: The storm *shut in* the travelers at the cabin.
She was *shut in* by her illness for weeks.

back.definition: a sound, especially one that is loud or unpleasant
examples: The *noise* from the construction site was unbearable.
I couldn't sleep because of the *noise* outside.

back.definition: making a lot of noise
examples: The *noisy* kids were playing in the street.
It was a very *noisy* party.

back.definition: without any noise; completely quiet
examples: The car was almost *noiseless* as it drove down the street.
They moved through the house in a *noiseless* manner.

back.definition: a natural oily substance found in animal bodies, often stored under the skin
examples: The doctor advised him to reduce his intake of *fat*.
The cat had a lot of *fat* on its belly.

back.definition: the state or condition of being fat or overweight
examples: His *fatness* made it difficult for him to move quickly.
They were concerned about the *fatness* of the livestock.

back.definition: to make or become fat or fatter, especially by eating more
examples: They wanted to *fatten* the turkey before Thanksgiving.
She was trying to *fatten* up for the winter.

back.definition: to not succeed in what you are trying to achieve or are expected to do
examples: He didn't want to *fail* the test.
She tried to start the engine, but it *failed*.

back.definition: firmly fixed, constant, not subject to change or variation
examples: He has a *steady* job at the factory.
She maintained a *steady* pace throughout the race.

back.definition: the quality of being steady, stable, and not changing
examples: His *steadiness* in the face of danger was admirable.
They appreciated the *steadiness* of her leadership.

back.definition: not firm, stable, or secure; shaky
examples: The table was *unsteady* and wobbled when touched.
He felt *unsteady* on his feet after the long flight.

back.definition: the state or feeling of grief when deprived of someone or something of value
examples: They suffered a great *loss* when their house burned down.
She felt a deep sense of *loss* after her friend's departure.

back.definition: a way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading
examples: We followed the *path* through the forest.
The garden has a winding *path* leading to the pond.

back.definition: a path or course taken by a person, animal, or thing
examples: The *pathway* to success is often difficult.
They walked along the *pathway* in the park.

back.definition: in a position with the top turned to the bottom.
examples: The picture was hung *upside down*.
He accidentally placed the book *upside down* on the shelf.

back.definition: comfortable, warm, and pleasant.
examples: The living room is very *cozy* during the winter.
She loves to read a book in her *cozy* chair.

back.definition: to represent or show something in a picture or story.
examples: The artist *depicted* a beautiful landscape.
The movie *depicts* the struggles of the early settlers.

back.definition: the way that something is represented or shown.
examples: The book's *depiction* of life in the city is quite realistic.
The *depiction* of the character in the film was very accurate.

back.definition: space that can be occupied or where something can be done.
examples: There's not enough *room* for all the furniture.
They made *room* for a new dining table.

back.definition: having a lot of space.
examples: The new car is very *roomy* inside.
They bought a *roomy* house to accommodate their growing family.

back.definition: a curved piece of glass or other transparent material, used in cameras, glasses, and scientific equipment.
examples: She adjusted the *lens* on her camera.
The *lens* of the microscope needs cleaning.

back.definition: the part that sticks out and can move at the back of the body of an animal, bird, or fish.
examples: The dog wagged its *tail* happily.
The cat's *tail* was bushy.

back.definition: the bottom or end part of something.
examples: The airplane's *tails* were painted red.
He cut the *tails* off the vegetables.

back.definition: having a tail.
examples: The *tailed* creatures were seen in the forest.
A long-*tailed* bird perched on the branch.

back.definition: a closed metal container, especially cylinder-shaped, in which some types of drink and food are sold.
examples: He drank a *can* of soda.
She opened a *can* of beans.

back.definition: preserved and stored in a can.
examples: They ate *canned* soup for lunch.
The *canned* food was stacked in the pantry.

back.definition: powder made from grain, especially wheat, used for making bread, cakes, pasta, pastry, etc.
examples: She added *flour* to the cake mixture.
The recipe calls for a cup of *flour*.

back.definition: a type of thin book with large pages and a paper cover that contains articles and photographs and is published every week or month.
examples: She read an interesting article in the *magazine*.
He subscribed to a fashion *magazine*.

back.definition: (of a person) nervous and worried and unable to relax.
examples: She felt very *tense* before the exam.
His shoulders were *tense* with stress.

back.definition: a feeling of nervousness before an important or difficult event.
examples: The *tension* in the room was palpable.
There was a lot of *tension* before the meeting.

back.definition: a method, style, or manner of doing something.
examples: She found a new *way* to solve the problem.
There are many *ways* to cook an egg.

back.definition: to (cause to) divide into two or more parts, especially along a particular line.
examples: They *split* the bill equally.
The log was *split* into two pieces.

back.definition: to make a sound, especially by hitting a piece of metal against another piece of metal; to telephone someone
examples: The phone started to *ring* loudly.
He *rang* the bell to get attention.

back.definition: the sound a bell makes
examples: I heard the *ring* of the doorbell.
The *ring* of the school bell signaled the end of the day.

back.definition: a circular piece of jewellery worn especially on your finger
examples: She wore a beautiful diamond *ring*.
He gave her a gold *ring* for their anniversary.

back.definition: the short, thick finger on the side of your hand
examples: He gave a *thumbs*-up to show approval.
She accidentally hit her *thumb* with a hammer.

back.definition: a line that divides two areas or forms an edge around an area
examples: The fence marks the *boundary* of the property.
They crossed the *boundary* into the neighboring country.

back.definition: a particular amount of money that is paid to an employee, especially for each hour worked
examples: He earns a decent *wage* for his work.
The company increased the minimum *wage*.

back.definition: the meaning or most important part of what someone says or writes
examples: The *point* of the story is to be kind.
She made a good *point* during the discussion.

back.definition: having no purpose and it is a waste of time doing it
examples: It is *pointless* to argue with him.
The meeting felt completely *pointless*.

back.definition: to support or prefer one particular possibility
examples: Many people *favor* reducing taxes.
She tends to *favor* a more traditional approach.

back.definition: something you do to help someone
examples: Can you do me a *favor*?
She asked him for a *favor*.

back.definition: best liked or most enjoyed
examples: Chocolate is my *favourite* flavor.
This is my *favourite* book.

back.definition: showing that you like or approve of someone or something
examples: The proposal received a *favorable* response.
Her performance received *favorable* reviews.

back.definition: showing that you do not like or approve of someone or something
examples: The weather conditions were *unfavorable* for sailing.
The project received *unfavorable* feedback.

back.definition: a skilled and trained cook who works in a hotel or restaurant, especially the most important cook
examples: The *chef* prepared a delicious meal.
She trained as a *chef* in Paris.

back.definition: large or of noticeable importance
examples: They made a *considerable* amount of progress.
The project required a *considerable* investment.

back.definition: very small and therefore not important or not worth considering
examples: The cost was not *inconsiderable*.
Her contribution was not *inconsiderable*.

back.definition: very many of the same type, or of different types
examples: The company has *multiple* locations worldwide.
He gave *multiple* reasons for his decision.

back.definition: to become less or to make something less
examples: They took steps to *lessen* the risk.
The pain will *lessen* over time.

back.definition: a building or place that is easily recognized, especially one that you can use to judge where you are
examples: The Eiffel Tower is a famous *landmark*.
They used the church as a *landmark* to find their way back.

back.definition: hard or firm, keeping a clear shape
examples: The table is made of *solid* wood.
The ice was *solid* enough to walk on.

back.definition: a type of plant whose leaves are used in cooking to give flavor to particular dishes or in making medicine
examples: She added fresh *herbs* to the soup.
They grow *herbs* in their garden.

back.definition: relating to or made from herbs
examples: She drinks *herbal* tea every morning.
They sell *herbal* remedies at the store.

back.definition: a subject that people talk or write about
examples: We discussed various *topics* during the meeting.
The main *topic* of conversation was the new project.

back.definition: relating to things that are happening or of interest at the present time
examples: The article covers many *topical* issues.
This show discusses *topical* events in politics.

back.definition: to cause someone pain or to injure them
examples: Be careful not to *hurt* yourself.
His words *hurt* her deeply.

back.definition: injured or in pain
examples: She felt *hurt* after the accident.
His *hurt* feelings were evident.

back.definition: an organization that is connected with or controlled by another, usually larger, organization
examples: The local club is an *affiliate* of the national organization.
Our company has several *affiliates* in different countries.

back.definition: a connection with a political party or religion, or with a larger organization
examples: He has no political *affiliation*.
Her *affiliation* with the charity is well known.

back.definition: an uncomfortable feeling of nervousness or worry about something that is happening or might happen in the future
examples: She felt a lot of *anxiety* before the exam.
His *anxiety* about the future is understandable.

back.definition: a raised line of water that moves across the surface of the sea, ocean, etc.
examples: The *waves* crashed against the shore.
We watched the surfers ride the *waves*.

back.definition: in the distant past
examples: *Long ago*, people lived without modern technology.
The castle was built *long ago*.

back.definition: an empty area that is available to be used
examples: There is plenty of *space* in the new office.
We need more *space* for the event.

back.definition: the area beyond the earth's atmosphere, where the stars and planets are
examples: Astronauts travel into *space*.
The study of *space* is fascinating.

back.definition: large and with a lot of space
examples: The apartment is very *spacious*.
They moved to a *spacious* house.

back.definition: relating to the position, area, and size of things
examples: He has excellent *spatial* awareness.
The *spatial* arrangement of the room is important.

back.definition: strong, thick string
examples: He tied the package with a *cord*.
The lamp's *cord* is too short.

back.definition: the ability to see
examples: Her *vision* is excellent.
He lost his *vision* in the accident.

back.definition: a person who has the ability to imagine how something will develop in the future
examples: She is considered a *visionary* in her field.
The company's founder was a true *visionary*.

back.definition: twelve
examples: He bought a *dozen* eggs.
There were a *dozen* people in the room.

back.definition: some; an amount that is not exact but is fewer than many
examples: We have *several* options to consider.
She has *several* friends in the city.

back.definition: the conditions that control an agreement, arrangement, or activity
examples: We need to agree on the *terms* of the contract.
The *terms* of the deal were favorable.

back.definition: willing to give more of something, especially money, than is strictly necessary or expected
examples: She is very *generous* with her time.
He made a *generous* donation to the charity.

back.definition: the quality of being kind and generous
examples: Her *generosity* knows no bounds.
We were touched by his *generosity* towards the less fortunate.

back.definition: a part of the coast where the land curves inwards so that the sea is surrounded by land on three sides
examples: We sailed into the *bay* at sunset.
The small *bay* was perfect for swimming.

back.definition: a moral or legal obligation; a responsibility
examples: It is your *duty* to vote.
She felt it was her *duty* to care for her parents.

back.definition: performing the duties expected or required of one; characterized by doing one's duty
examples: He is a *dutiful* son.
She carried out her tasks in a *dutiful* manner.

back.definition: a structured set of data held in a computer, especially one that is accessible in various ways
examples: We need to update the *database* regularly.
The *database* contains information on all our clients.

back.definition: to cause someone to take a course of action
examples: The incident *prompted* an investigation.
His remarks *prompted* me to rethink my position.

back.definition: done without delay; immediate
examples: She gave a *prompt* reply.
The service was very *prompt*.

back.definition: a word or phrase spoken as a reminder to an actor of a forgotten word or line
examples: The actor needed a *prompt* during the performance.
She provided a *prompt* when he forgot his lines.

back.definition: to watch carefully the way something happens or the way someone does something, especially in order to learn more about it
examples: He likes to *observe* birds in their natural habitat.
We will *observe* the reaction to the new policy.

back.definition: the action or process of closely observing or monitoring something or someone
examples: The patient is under close *observation*.
His *observations* were very insightful.

back.definition: a person who watches or notices something
examples: He is a keen *observer* of human nature.
The *observer* noted several discrepancies.

back.definition: to cause or allow liquid to flow over the edge of its container, especially unintentionally
examples: She accidentally *spilled* coffee on the table.
Be careful not to *spill* the paint.

back.definition: lasting only a short period of time
examples: They had a *brief* conversation.
I will be *brief* in my explanation.

back.definition: the part of a person's or animal's body connecting the head to the rest of the body
examples: She wore a scarf around her *neck*.
Giraffes have long *necks*.

back.definition: the aggregate of people living together in a more or less ordered community
examples: We live in a diverse *society*.
The changes affected the whole *society*.

back.definition: relating to society or social relations
examples: The project aims to address *societal* issues.
There are many *societal* norms that influence behavior.

back.definition: lacking physical strength and energy
examples: After the illness, she felt very *weak*.
He has a *weak* handshake.

back.definition: the state or condition of lacking strength
examples: His *weakness* was evident during the match.
Chocolate is her greatest *weakness*.

back.definition: to make or become weaker in power, resolve, or physical strength
examples: The medication can *weaken* your immune system.
His resolve began to *weaken* after many setbacks.

back.definition: to cause a particular situation to happen
examples: The new policy *resulted in* higher productivity.
His negligence *resulted in* an accident.
